data.title: Keywords are not getting highlighted with 0.10.10 release
data.body:
Just updated my Visual Studio Code to 0.10.10. It not longer highlights JavaScript keywords  like function, let, const, yield, etc.

Details:
OS: Linux Mint 17.3 64 bit
Code: 0.10.10 64 bit

data.title: [Intellisense] Intellisense pop-up is not displaying at right position and options are misleading.
data.body:
OS: Windows 10

Steps:
1. Launch VS code.
2. Open C# coded UI project.
3. Updated field name for class object to get some compilation error.
4. Click on intellisense icon to fix the error.
4. Verify suggested options in intellisense pop-up and try to apply.
Actual:
1.  Intellisense Pop-up is displaying at wrong position.
2. Options like " Create Field", "Create property" are not working (no action when user tries to fix with those options).
3. Once user apply the given options then it should not display again but when I selected option "Declare local variable" then it is showing same option again in intellisense pop-up though action has been taken (in my case I applied "created local variable" and local variable has been created but I am getting same option again and each time when I select that I will create a new variable") .

Expected: User should not get redundant options like "Create Field", "Create Local Variable", "Create property" etc. The correct option for end user is "Generate field in class.

![irrelevant-options-declare local variable](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13658026/9ebee418-e628-11e5-910d-5021ae7b18de.png)
![pop-up position](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13658025/9eabc9fa-e628-11e5-9c87-7154c23d569e.png)

Actual:

data.title: fix activate extension telemetry event to include
data.body: I noticed that eager extensions activation events were not being caught previously as they don't go through `_actualActivateExtension`. I am moving the reporting to `_doActualActivateExtension` where I think we catch all the activation scenarios for all events.

data.title: Updated code command in bash (OS X) not working
data.body:
I recently updated to the new version of code (0.10.10) on OS X, and I was asked to remove an existing `code` alias I had set up in bash. I did so by modifying my `.bashrc` and then allowed code to apply its own. But the new one doesn't work after restarting code and bash:

```
$ code
  File "<string>", line 1
    import os,sys; print os.path.realpath(sys.argv[1])
                          ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
/usr/local/bin/code: line 10: ./MacOS/Electron: No such file or directory
```

data.title: Javascript colorization defining multiple var
data.body:
When defining multiple var in JavaScript the colorization is not working properly after the first defined variable if they are on separate lines. 

![varcolor](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13656001/3a3e5a38-e618-11e5-8e29-f01b87bf83cc.JPG)
`var wm1 = new WeakMap(),
    wm2 = new WeakMap(),
    wm3 = new WeakMap();`

On the same line they are correctly colorized 
![varcolorworking](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13656046/80e0f5f4-e618-11e5-82a2-f729c81ce286.JPG)

Expected: wm2 and wm3 should be the same color as wm1 regardless of the line they are on.

Version 0.10.12-alpha
Commit e8d5a7932b99f6b7559d48536bfc84732bfc8582

data.title: Rename symbol on a HTML tag inside of JSX globally renames all tags
data.body:
1. Open a project that uses TypeScript + JSX (with react.d.ts loaded)
2. Put the cursor over a common HTML tag like `<div>`
3. Hit F2 to rename symbol
4. Rename the div to something else (like span)

Expected: Just the matching open/close is renamed to `<span>`
Actual: Every div in **every** JSX file is now a span and even react.d.ts has had its div attribute in the HTML tag names renamed to span

VS Code version: 0.10.10

data.title: Intellisense for nodejs doesn't work without a jsconfig.json after 0.10.10
data.body:
I found this going through the /docs/runtimes/Node.js walkthrough after seeing a doc feedback verbatim saying that typings weren't being picked up.
After creating an express application, trying to get IntelliSense for node and express types fails.
If I roll-back to 0.10.8, the typings are picked up correctly.
The generated express app does not include a jsconfig.json file.

data.title: Images / media files cause error in git preview

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a small issue but happens to me often. 

I can see .png and other media files fine until I use git features in VS Code. When I click on an image in the git viewlet I get the following error. 

```
Error: Unable to open "<image name>": File seems to be binary and cannot be opened as text. 
```

This may be intended behavior, but I believe it should be changed. I'd like to see the image and not have to see an error each time I click on a file.

data.title: [php] opening php tag should be recognised as a valid intellisense option
data.body:
As I type `<?php` in vscode I keep getting caught up with the `php_ini_loaded_file` autocomplete:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038062/13648765/4529e1a0-e632-11e5-99ff-696e596551c1.png)

It works if I type `<?php` (space) but often times I am wanting to go to the next line to start writing a multiline block of php code. If you press enter then it autocompletes the line to:

```
<?php_ini_loaded_file
```

The system should recognise that typing `<?php` (enter/return) is a valid option.

data.title: Font Size isn't consistent with other editors
data.body:
I have noticed that the rendered font size in VS Code is quite a bit smaller than other popular editors for the same font face. In General, I have to set a font size to 15 or 16 to match a 12 pt font in something like sublime. I Have included several screenshots of my windows 8 computer, with the monitor set to 1280x720 (to keep the images small & the differences noticeable), with side by side comparisons of VS Code, Sublime 3, and Word (for reference).

Notice that VS Code is at 16 pt font, and sublime and word are at 12pt font, and they are all darn close to showing the same # of lines. The line spacing also isn't significantly different.

My VS Code Settings
![vs code settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1072285/13648263/fca8f7aa-e5f4-11e5-9085-085f2b15cadf.png)

My Sublime settings
![sublime-settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1072285/13648280/0d9df8d0-e5f5-11e5-83e6-94b04c435597.png)

VS Code and Sublime side by side
![vscode vs sublime](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1072285/13648284/10674378-e5f5-11e5-95a8-0135e20630d3.png)

Settings in Word
![word settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1072285/13648285/12c912f4-e5f5-11e5-8dd9-fc453708782b.png)

VS Code & Word Side by Side
![word vs vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1072285/13648287/153cbb9e-e5f5-11e5-92c2-7c7c89a6cea5.png)

Here I set both Sublime and VS Code to 16 pt font. The difference is stark.
![sublime at 16 pt](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1072285/13648382/81b1569a-e5f5-11e5-82dd-fe9269c0db52.png)

And Finally, I have put the same word side by side with sublime and VS Code both at 16 pt font. Sublime has the dark background, VS Code the light one
![words at 16 pt](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1072285/13648433/cd75e730-e5f5-11e5-8603-a03c4900c874.png)

data.title: preLaunchTask: isWatching & relaunching

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
As suggested by @isidorn in #2086 I'm creating a separate issue. Seems to be relevant o #3669 as well.

So the problem is, if I have a persistent background task that I want to assign as a `preLaunchtask` and...
A. ...**`isWatchnig` isn't set**: the launch command starts only the task so you need hit F5 once more (while the task is running) to actually launch the project. If you terminate the task after the first launch - the new launch will again only start the task.
B. ...**`isWatching` is set to true**: the first launch starts only the task like above, but the second one throws a prompt `"There is an active running task right now. Terminate it first before executing another task."[Terminate/Close]`. you would expect VSCode continue launch attempt after you select to terminate the task or ignore it but no. Whatever you choose you need to launch it again starting the loop of fail.

In my previous issue people seemed to be focused on the flaws of the tasks and only fixed that part. But I'm personally as a user don't so much care if and how tasks are handled, rather I'm annoyed by the fact that every re/launch I get prompted or warned of things not directly relevant to my project. My main complaint is that the launch spawns prompts at all. Every coding session means re/launching the project 3 dozen times. **any interrupts regarding background deamons unless its something critical are breaking the workflow.** For example I don't really care that #2086 was partually fixed because I still get prompted and as a result I turn `preLaunchTask` off completely thus any improvement in this regard is nil for me. So again: There should be an additional setting for either silently restarting the `preLaunchTask` or silently skip the task launch and assuming that the already running one should run until the end of the current session. And/or there should be a default based on the either - in any case prompting is not an option. 

Here is the [test case](/Spown/pltb). **Ideally the `preLaunchTask` (a gulp-watching one) should run only once. Any subsequent re/launch shouldn't prompt me to terminate it** (If I need to I can do it manually at any point) or warn me (just log it somewhere, idc) or anything else. Launch process should only be interrupted by errors caused by the launched project. Background staff shouldn't have the power to interrupt it.

thanx

data.title: VSCode corrupts multi-line environment variables
data.body:
On Fedora installations with some packages installed, e.g. `environment-modules-3.2.10-16.fc22.x86_64` , `scl-utils-2.0.1-3.fc22.x86_64`, shell functions are exported in the environment:

```
$ printenv

BASH_FUNC_module()=() {  eval `/usr/bin/modulecmd bash $*`
}
BASH_FUNC_scl()=() {  local CMD=$1;
 if [ "$CMD" = "load" -o "$CMD" = "unload" ]; then
 eval "module $@";
 else
 /usr/bin/scl "$@";
 fi
}
```

It seems something in VS Code is misparsing or corrupting these variable definitions, because various shell commands (e.g. a build task) then output things like

```
/bin/sh: module: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_module'
/bin/sh: scl: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file
/bin/sh: error importing function definition for `BASH_FUNC_scl'
```

before or after their real output. This obviously confuses problem matchers, `showOutput` and the like.

data.title: "let" colorization on Javascript (ES6) changed with update to Version 0.10.10 (0.10.10)
data.body:
After I got the update to Version 0.10.10 (0.10.10) for OSX, the Javascript "let" keyword is now white (used to be blue, recognized as a reserved word).

I tried adding back the jsconfig.json (which I understand is no longer needed to enable ES6) and the colorization is still no good.

I wonder if other keywords are being colorized incorrectly.

data.title: Output handling improvements
data.body:
**Assignees:**
- [x] Windows @bpasero 
- [x] OS X @waderyan  
- [x] Linux @aeschli 

We are handling output in a better way. Related issues #3609, #3896, #3897. Verify:
- You can not cause VSCode to freeze or crash by spamming it with output from an extension
- No duplicate output is received, nor any output is missing - particularly if you open and close the output panel

data.title: php v5.4 short array syntax not supported
data.body:
Since PHP v5.4 it has supported a short array syntax which replaces `array()` with `[]`:

```
<?php
$array = array(
    "foo" => "bar",
    "bar" => "foo",
);

// as of PHP 5.4
$array = [
    "foo" => "bar",
    "bar" => "foo",
];
?>
```

http://php.net/manual/en/language.types.array.php#example-96

I'm using Visual Studio Code v0.10.10

```
Version 0.10.10
Commit 5b5f4db87c10345b9d5c8d0bed745bcad4533135
Date 2016-03-07T10:38:23.764Z
Shell 0.35.6
Renderer 45.0.2454.85
Node 4.1.1
```

Every time it comes across one of these it shows highlight errors:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038062/13643752/345b1bd6-e61a-11e5-9eba-619676bd4c49.png)

and

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1038062/13643767/425390d8-e61a-11e5-9979-7c45ad023f3e.png)

Implementing #776 should fix this issue as well.

data.title: Indentation improvements
data.body:
**Assignees:**
- [x] Windows @gregvanl 
- [x] OS X @bpasero  
- [x] Linux @joaomoreno 

We have improved our indentation support. Verify:
### New defaults
- By default we ship with `editor.detectIndentation` = true, `editor.tabSize` = 4, `editor.insertSpaces` = false.
- When `editor.detectIndentation` is set to true, and the file has sufficient hints (it is not empty, it has indented content), `editor.tabSize` and `editor.insertSpaces` will be guessed from the file contents.
- Since the detection code now kicks in by default, please **open some files from other OSS projects** and check if the indentation is guessed correctly.
- **Migration story**: Make sure you get a warning and a notification message if either `editor.tabSize`, `editor.inserSpaces` are set to `'auto'` and a custom hover message on the values in settings.

> Note: By design, `editor.tabSize` will be guessed only to 2, 4, 6 or 8.
### Status Bar
- Status bar always shows indentation status and clicking on it shows indentation actions
- 'Detect indentation from Content' guesses the indentation in the current editor from the content
- All the configured indentation is preserved in a vscode session for a file - if you open the same file in a new editor it should have the same indentation settings

Moving from https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-roslyn/issues/420

After compiling and putting `omnisharp-roslyn-dev` `OmniSharp.exe` in place in order to get VS Code working happily with `dotnet cli` right now ...

``` json
"csharp.omnisharp": 
    "C:\\omnisharp-roslyn-dev\\artifacts\\publish\\OmniSharp\\dnxcore50\\OmniSharp.exe",
```

I'm getting this VS Code issue ...

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1622880/13609556/4df0e678-e50e-11e5-8e55-cfda89f70eae.PNG)

The replaced OmniSharp seems to be working ok ... IntelliSense and CodeLens seem ok. The exception seems to just be an artifact of replacing the default OmniSharp.

Anything to be concerned about? Should I just ignore this until updated VS Code tooling is released and I can drop the dev repo version?

data.title: TS arrow functions in classes break theme coloring.
data.body:
Adding an arrow function to a TS class breaks the VSCode theme. Compare this screenshot:

![before-arrow-function](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2417276/13641293/8111095a-e5dd-11e5-8dea-7c61de385ffc.png)

To this one, after changing the `Test` function to an arrow function:

![after-arrow-function](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2417276/13641299/86fc9816-e5dd-11e5-8f94-068f447ed4fc.png)

I've tested this in both the Dark default and Light default theme, bug is present in both themes. It's also present in both .ts and .tsx files. I'm using VSCode version 0.10.10.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a new TS file and give it a class.
2. Add two normal functions to that class (i.e. `public SomeMethod() { } public OtherMethod() { }` ).
3. Change the first function to an arrow function ( `public SomeMethod = () => { }` ).
4. Theme colors on all functions below `SomeMethod` are now broken.
